Description: Rim and body sherd of Aeolian black-figured pottery plate; black band on top of flat ledge rim; on floor, diagonal chevrons between narrow dilute bands as stand line for black-figure decoration of which only the end of bird's tail with feathers in added red and white is preserved; exterior: black on edge of rim and band in added red over top; below, wide black band on underside of rim; below, two concentric grooves at centre of sherd with two black bands.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Modern inscription written in ink 'NAU 13' on break (accession number used in clay analysis). According to Dupont and Thomas (2006, p. 80, NAU13), the geophysical characteristics of the fabric indicate that the sherd originated in Aeolis (North Ionia or Samos in an earlier communication, 30/1 May 1978).
Bibliographic references: Dupont & Thomas 2006 / Naukratis: Les Importations Grecques Orientales Archaïques (p. 78, 80, 82-83) (NAU 13)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GK.47)
